turn.text: Well, our argument is that unless or until there is a finding that there is a lack of a reasonable relationship under whatever level of judicial scrutiny might be given to government's justification between the practice of double-bunking and the government – legitimate governmental objectives that might support that practice, the practice stands –-

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In other words you don't accept my, the series suggested in my question.
Do you think that it violated the Due Process Clause even if it is not punishment [Voice Overlap]

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: We think that it could, but that is because we don't think the concept of punishment has a useful role to play in an analyzing the due process plan.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Then how was the Due Process Clause implicated?

Obviously, I think everybody would agree that government cannot punish somebody until or unless he's convicted of a criminal offense beyond a reasonable doubt and therefore you can't take a pretrial detainee and put him or do anything else, that's obviously punishment.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now that would clearly implicate the Due Process Clause in this case of the Fifth Amendment, but absent a finding a punishment how is the Due Process Clause involved?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well, that now depends upon what view you take.

The view that you have taken in the Moore case I believe and perhaps in other places is that it has to be one of a specific category of interest that are fundamental and that are subjected to searching scrutiny and punishment would be such an --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: [Voice Overlap] Constitution and then in order to find the answer to a constitutional question you look at the Constitution, don't you?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well, I understood the Moore case to suggest that there were five votes on this Court at least for the proposition that the due process concept is a rational continuum in Justice Harlan's words and that is not include just a series of points that are picked out.
In our view of course it doesn't matter for the disposition of this case.
We were entitled to hearing to show the reasons why and to explore the effects of the conditions.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, if its punishment, all the reasons in the world wouldn't make this constitutional, would it, if you show there are good reasons to whip these people once a day?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: I agree, if its punishment, we would be defendants.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Then there wouldn't be no [Voice Overlap] at all constitutionally?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: [Inaudible] cells were six -- they had ten square feet and then when two people, just room for two chairs and they kept them in there 24 hours a day, would you think you could be enjoined from --

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: On grounds of the Due Process Clause?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well, yes on the grounds of the Due Process Clause, now, there are there are two separate ways however to look at the due process analysis.
One, is an importation of the Eighth Amendment Standard into to Due Process Clause and the second is to view it independently as a liberty interest not to be subjected to over crowding --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But that involves punishment, doesn't it, the Eighth Amendment?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well the Court --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That means that there is some punishment.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: The Court has, has I think the courts have approached that concept in a pragmatic way that is they're prepared to say the conditions of confinement that fall below minimal standards of decency to constitute punishment.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Let me get one thing straight.
I take it you – you'd making the same argument here if this facility had been deserve the way it's been used?
It would be, you know, perhaps isn't relevant but it isn't crucial that it was planned to hold X number and all of a sudden it had the whole 2X.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well the case might be different because the Court of Appeals made it per say probation turned upon the design quality or the aspect of the case.
It was designed for one person they said you cannot two people in a room designed for one.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well my question still is if it has been designed the way it has been used you would be still be here defending it?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: We would defend it of course.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Won in the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: We might have won in the Court of Appeals, that was the point I was trying to say.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Fery, with respect to the publisher-only rule you indicate in your briefs as I remember that the government is now changed as practice and policy and there's no longer enforced such rule with respect to paperback books?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And therefore to that extent you're not –

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: We're not asking you to –

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: planning about asking that the court of appeal's judgment be disturbed in that aspect?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now how about the more general change of conditions in the overcrowding in this facility?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Isn't it -- don't you represent to us now that there is no more overcrowding?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: We have explained to the Court that we have been able to comply with the outstanding injunction because the number of pretrial detainees has at present is dramatically lower than it was two years ago.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But you're still complaining?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: We still take the position, the population in the institution at present is fluctuating at or near 449 people the present capacity --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's designed for 449?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: It's designed for 449.
The present capacity in terms of numbers of beds as hired because there are 30 extra beds in the dormitory, so actually up to 479 could be held.

In fact, as a practical matter you can't always do it because you have classifications that is you have a unit for women, male prisoners are not put in that unit, you might have 10 empty beds in there but you simply can't use them and there are other kinds of problems like that.

But it is our position that an injunction has been issued against us that we believe is improper and unauthorized and without constitutional basis and that we would if the need arose again and it may, resort to double-bunking --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So you would vigorously object any suggestion that this case is moot?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well I don't know, I don't -- we would object to a disposition that involved let's say I dismissal of the writ.
I don't know that we would object to a disposition of vacating the injunction and remanding it.
We just think that under the -- I think United States V. W. T. Grant is a case which indicates that it would not be moot where we say that we will again do what the injunction prohibited.

I don't know in the District Court when it gets back there if you do reverse whether there will be a meaningful controversy because I don't know how the District Court is going to decide whether double-bunking is justified at a time when it's not --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: When it doesn't exist.

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: doesn't exist.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do I understand the government concedes or taking no position on the question of a writ of habeas corpus is subject to a class action, not a very important question?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: It may be a very important question.
My understanding and when I made inquiry about that I was advised that there is some Court of Appeals' authority to the affect that habeas corpus this class action --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: None here --

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: -- there is none here I am simply --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Don't you think that's an important question in this case?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: I think it's an important question.
I don't think it's an important question in this case because we didn't raise it until, well perhaps it would have been an important question that we might have raised.
I don't mean to facetious.
I am not clear that it's before the Court presently for decision --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But there's no jurisdiction, it's before the Court whether anyone raised it or not?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well, but there is a distinction between the kind of subject matter jurisdiction in habeas corpus over a claim and the question of whether class action was improperly certified.
We do have another --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But this one which deserves some exploration, would you not agree?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well, we would be prepared if the Court wants us to research the question and submit our views on it.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: No we'll pass on that later.
We'll resume -- excuse me, we'll resume arguments at 1 o'clock, but subject to Mr. Justice White's question.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Yes, you won't be back at 1 o'clock?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I might if you're asking.
Mr. Frey, do you think the issue on the books is moot, is that what you're suggesting?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Now we're not suggesting that at all.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What are you suggesting?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: We are suggesting that we are not requesting relief except as regards --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Where do you put – you raised this question in your petition?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: We have raised in our petition.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And you've briefed it?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well, the way we've – at the time that we brief that the policy had already been changed and our briefing was intended to focus.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So does that mean that the issue has become moot since the filing the petition for certiorari?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: Well, I think if the hardcover books were not involved, and the injunction had been issued only against soft cover books then I think they should be moot.
As I was saying earlier because we have not intention --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And the injunction would then be vacated to that extent?

turn.speaker: andrew_l_frey
turn.label: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
turn.text: I guess, I am not sure that it would draw a matter of something.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you.
The case is submitted.
